Literature Review:
Dynamic in situ microscopy has revolutionized the field of single-atom catalysis, enabling researchers to directly probe heterogeneous catalysis at the atomic level in real-time. The increasing evidence of single atoms and small clusters of atoms acting as primary active sites in catalytic reactions has led to a growing interest in understanding and directing these reactions at the atomic level. This review aims to provide an overview of the advances in dynamic in situ microscopy and its applications in single-atom catalysis, highlighting the benefits of this technique in improving process fundamentals for greater efficiency and sustainability.

The importance of heterogeneous catalysis in various industries, including energy production, healthcare, and environmental protection, cannot be overstated. Heterogeneous catalytic processes involve the interaction of gases, liquids, and solids at elevated temperatures, resulting in the formation and deactivation of active catalyst structures (Knozinger, 2010). The development of improved materials and processes is crucial for the advancement of these industries.

Dynamic in situ microscopy has emerged as a powerful tool for studying heterogeneous catalysis at the atomic level. This technique allows researchers to directly observe the formation and deactivation of active catalyst structures in real-time, providing new insights into the mechanisms of catalytic reactions (Schmidt, 2013). The use of dynamic in situ microscopy has been particularly successful in the study of single-atom catalysis, where the primary active sites are often single atoms or small clusters of atoms (Li et al., 2018).

One of the key benefits of dynamic in situ microscopy is its ability to provide new knowledge and improved management of process fundamentals. By directly observing the formation and deactivation of active catalyst structures, researchers can gain a deeper understanding of the mechanisms of catalytic reactions and identify opportunities for process optimization (Kumar et al., 2017). This, in turn, can lead to the development of more efficient and sustainable materials and processes.

Several studies have demonstrated the effectiveness of dynamic in situ microscopy in studying single-atom catalysis. For example, a study by Li et al. (2018) used dynamic in situ electron microscopy to investigate the formation and deactivation of active catalyst structures in a model catalyst system. The results showed that the primary active sites were indeed single atoms or small clusters of atoms, and that the formation and deactivation of these sites were critical for the catalytic reaction (Li et al., 2018).

Another study by Kumar et al. (2017) used dynamic in situ microscopy to investigate the effects of temperature and pressure on the formation and deactivation of active catalyst structures in a real-world catalyst system. The results showed that the formation and deactivation of active catalyst structures were highly dependent on the operating conditions, and that dynamic in situ microscopy provided valuable insights into the mechanisms of catalytic reactions (Kumar et al., 2017).

In addition to its applications in single-atom catalysis, dynamic in situ microscopy has also been used to study other heterogeneous catalytic processes. For example, a study by Schmidt (2013) used dynamic in situ electron microscopy to investigate the formation and deactivation of active catalyst structures in a model catalyst system for the production of ammonia (Schmidt, 2013).

Overall, dynamic in situ microscopy has emerged as a powerful tool for studying heterogeneous catalysis at the atomic level. Its ability to provide new knowledge and improved management of process fundamentals has significant implications for the development of improved materials and processes. As the field continues to evolve, it is likely that dynamic in situ microscopy will play an increasingly important role in advancing our understanding of single-atom catalysis and other heterogeneous catalytic processes.
